data.title: Is this the fastest Nikon lens ever made?
data.meta_description:
Saw this and it got me to wondering?
http://tokyocamerastyle.com/
data.text:
No, it's not.

The fastest F-mount lens for 35mm SLRs is f/1.2, and there have been several models of this speed, with focal lengths of 50 to 58mm. I believe the geometry of the mount makes f/1.2 the limit, and I know that the early pre-AI photomic meters also had this limit fixed in their metering system.

As far as I can tell, that f/1.1 lens may be the fastest lens for the 35mm format Nikon made, but it's for the rangefinders, not the more famous F mount SLRs.

If you leave the 35mm format, Nikon made a 35mm f/0.9, faster than either of these. There may be other faster lenses I'm missing.

http://homepage2.nifty.com/akiyanroom/redbook-e/repro/tv.html

Nikon (Nippon Kogaku) make lenses for all sorts of applications in scientific instrumentation and industrial imaging. I would be very surprised if a simple camera lens had the fastest aperture they ever made. For instance, I think some of their microscope objectives have a higher relative aperture than f/1.1.

In any case, who cares? F/1.1 or f/0.9; they're only a 2/3rds or just over 1 stop faster than the common f/1.4 lenses.

Nikon includes RF as well as SLR. How soon we forget.

I do believe that the f/1.1 is the fastest production Nikon lens.
The fastest production SLR lenses are the various f/1.2 lenses, again, so far as I can find out. A few faster (f/1.0 or even f/0.95) lenses may have been prototyped, but not produced.

Other manufacturers (Leica, Canon) did market a few faster lenses.

Of course, 8mm and 16mm and other small format lenses are often produced in very wide apertures. I don't know about Nikon making any f/1.0 lenses in those formats.
